metadata.name: In the Edge #179
metadata.description:
./ In the Edge

It's been a long time since your journey began, caring for the ones you love, pursuing your dreams, and giving the best of you. 

Now you know you can't go back, you can't go further, you know your time is coming.

How far did you go? It doesn't matter, you did it right. Your accomplishments will serve well the next generations in their journeys, in their search for themselves.

Now it's time to stop, time to take a moment and contemplate the vast universe.

Soon all of this will be ending.

You did it right.

Embrace the void.
=========
=========


./ Color scheme (feature)
There are 12 color schemes and with each set, specific arrays for color collections for the space, stars, planet, and accent colors. 

These are color schemes in the known universe of "In the Edge":
- Mars visions
- Cyberpunk
- Unknown passenger 
- Renegade
- Primary
- Coral
- r.e.d.
- Machines of an ancient-future 
- The void
- Tinted light 
- Malibu dreams
- Atari (horrendous brown, red and yellowish combinations... I love it)

./ Mountain type (feature)
In the Edge, you will find a mountain, and that mountain will be special, which type will you find?

- Parallela insolitum
- Sandy dunes of the truth
- Wavy uncertainty
- Intrinsic soul ridges
- Cerritulus formationis

./ Mountain direction (feature)
Life is about direction... mountains too.

- Left
- Right
- Left-Right

./ Space scenery
This is the spicy touch, some of the iterations will have animation and others will not, giving you a clear view of the magnificent space in front of you.

- Clean (NOT animated)
- Windy planet (animated)
- Topographic planet (animated)
- Meteor shower (animated)

./ Distance from Earth (feature)
How far did you go? Your travel could be from 1 lightyear to 999,999,999 lightyears (that's a lot of lights and years!). However just a few will pass the barrier of 99,999,999ly.

// Additional perks
./ Planet names 
Planet names are unique and they are conformed by three blocks.

The first block is a conjunction between ancient Latin names and Japanese last names. 

The second block takes the last three characters from the fxhash.

The third block takes three numbers from the number seed obtained from fxrand().

The planet you land will be unique, as unique as you are.

// Controls
./ Pause-Play animation
Because maybe (and just maybe) you want to freeze the perfect moment before closing your eyes.

[Backspace] Pause.
[Enter] Play

Applies to "Space scenery" features windy planet, topographic planet, and meteor shower.

metadata.name: Up Above #157
metadata.description:
This piece is inspired by the feeling of insignificance. This feeling, which we all share and feel at some points in our lives is often referred to as negative. But I feel quite the contrary, this feeling is quite beautiful, as it shows small parts together can form something big.

We are but a speck in the universe, like a grain of sand on a beach, like a single drop of water in an ocean, like a single leaf on a tree. But together we are a forest, a river, a sea. Together we are the universe.

Feel free to explore this piece for as long as you want, and feel free to export it in any way you like, and use it for thing like prints, and, of course, I'd love to know about them :)

---

To export your iteration, click the menu bar at the bottom of the screen and press either the "Export current" or "Export custom" button.

metadata.name: fxhash SpeedRun: any% < 960 minutes #211
metadata.description: A performance piece. From cloning the template to a decent piece in less than 960 minutes.

metadata.name: Anachronous #90
metadata.description:
This project is about the exploration of chaotic structures created with lines and blurry silhouettes. They work together to make the shapes emerge without revealing them completely and create dark and light areas that compose a feeling of depth and weight to the scene.

Some pieces are chaotic, some more ordered. Some have strong compositions, some don't. By zooming in on the details we can let our mind wander and start seeing shapes.

Best experienced in full-screen.

Press S to take a screenshot
Press M to take a high resolution screenshot
Press H to take a higher resolution screenshot (may not work for some devices)

WARNING: Project is using webgl, it may not work on some older devices.

Original artwork by William Watkins · Lyon, 2022

metadata.name: g l a s s #981
metadata.description: i thought it looked cool

attributes.name: How much butter do you need?

metadata.name: (un)existing #27
metadata.description:
The existing nature grows on the unexisting spirits.

Generative sketch, based on the pen and ink drawings of Po Sheng Chen. Po Sheng Chen is an Architect who has drawn nothing but Architecture for over 25 years. He tried to explore something different from his previous style (Brutalism with Magical Realism), so developed his own Minimalist Architecture process and style. After breaking up all the complicated elements and symbols, he chose a simple and naive way to present “pure volumes in the space (the essential of Architecture)”: the Use of different densities of vertical lines to create different faces of volumes, with the addition of horizontal lines to create shadows on the volumes. Shadow determined the form of volumes, then they became a clear composition in the space, Eliminating chaos. These lines seem like spirits to Po Sheng Chen, because they represent the soul of Architecture, but they do not have a specific form or meaning...they are between existing and unexisting! Tezumie is a creative generative artist. He saw the latest experimental drawings of Po Sheng Chen, and after reaching out, the collab was formed with the goal of creating a digital representation of the original concept surrounded by a natural and overgrown environment. The combination of nature and architecture.

Made in p5js.

metadata.name: life is a (beautiful) mess #85
metadata.description:
when carefully applied, chaos brings things to life.

'life is a (beautiful) mess' was created as i led a certain amount of chaos take control of an animated textile algorithm i'm developing. 
as soon as it happened i realized that it was a great representation of our lives. 
each line represents one of us and the patterns that appear repeatedly are the situations we live which make us move, feel and be in a certain way. 
the image created is the sum of our paths in this life, as they only make sense when we look at them as one.

---

i hope you find it pleasant to watch this animation, how it develops and grows during aprox 1'30"
there are pieces drawn with the 4 typical school pen colors: black, green, blue and red. also a multicolor and a rare dark mode features.


press [s] to capture an image .png
press [r] to reload the animation
click the mouse to stop the animation
doubleclick the mouse to resume the animation

generative art created by mehno using p5js

metadata.name: Giants of the Meadow #33
metadata.description:
For my first drop on the new fxhash v1.0 I wanted to make something different. So I challenged myself to write a raymarcher like the ones I use in my shaders but in p5.js and make a fully procedural scene with it. It's a bit tricky to work with vectors once you are used to GLSL, but I managed to write a decent algorithm that scans a grid and slowly draws the image. It draws it with circles and triangles for the grass. The first thing I used for testing was a SDF of a plane with some tall bars on it. Then I was trying different distortions on the shapes and in one moment the results gave me the idea of a scene with mushrooms and grass on an undulated terrain. Later I added a small river and a cloudy sky. I think I was inadvertently inspired by some children's books I had when I was a kid. 

Best viewed full screen.

Features:

Mood: happy - normal - melancholic - strange - sleepy
Mushrooms: 2 - 4 (sometimes one of the mushrooms can only be seen on full screen)
Mushroom height: short - medium - tall
Mushroom fatness: S - M - L - XL
Mushroom shape: 1 - 2 - 3- 4 - 5
Mushroom tilt
Flowers color: white - yellow - pink - cyan - multicolor
River: yes - no
Camera orientation: north - south

metadata.name: Metropolis IX #108
metadata.description:
We divide spaces into smaller spaces which we conquer and live in our solitude. We call that Metropolis.

Started this piece as a rule based generative art. Simply the algorithm takes a rectangle and throws 2 random points inside it within defined x and y distances. Then using those 2 points, algorithm draws another rectangle and assigns letters to the corners of rectangle "A,B,C,D" starting from top left corner in clockwise direction. Then it starts to draw cells from inner rectangle's corner A to parent's corner A and goes on. Once 4 cells are created, it creates 4 more cells in between other cells, thus dividing a rectangle into 9 pieces. This is where "IX" comes from. Depending on the cell properties; algorithm assigns circles, triangles, lines and points to cells creating a city scape when certain parameters are given to the division algorithm.

There are 18 possible outcomes:
"Hazy Day" 13% probability (half of this style will come with slightly more color transition)
"Hazy Night" 10% probability
"Crystal Day" 11% probability
"Crystal Night" 5% probability
"Mondrian Day"  3% probability
"Mondrian Night" 3% probability
"Bauhaus Day" 3% probability
"Bauhaus Night" 3% probability
"1 Chroma Day" 4% probability (Multiple values of a single hue on a monochrome gradient)
"Mondrian Crystal Day" 3% probability
"Mondrian Crystal Night" 3% probability
"Monochrome Day" 3% probability 
"Monochrome Night" 4% probability 
"Vibrant Day" 12% probability
"Vibrant Night" 9% probability
"Rainbow Day' 5% probability
"Rainbow Night' 3% probability
"Chaotic Day"   3% probability (which takes pretty random parameters and 25% of this outcome has probability of creating very first coloring style of the project, see console for the hidden feature)




Press "1" to download 1000px height PNG
Press "2" to download 2000px height PNG
Press "3" to download 3000px height PNG
Press "4" to download 4000px height PNG
Press "5" to download 5000px height PNG
Press "6" to download 6000px height PNG
Press "7" to download 7000px height PNG
Press "8" to download 8000px height PNG
Press "9" to download 12000px height PNG
Press "m' to download 900x1600px PNG for mobile wallpaper

Use CTRL+SHIFT+C or CMD+SHIFT+C to open console for hidden features

Created from scratch with p5.js 
Murat Atimtay 2022 | @atimtay | www.muratatimtay.com

metadata.name: Mount Doodle #167
metadata.description:
Tried my best to make every doodle aesthetically pleasing to the eyes.
However, just like nature, beauty often lies in imperfections. :)

Made with p5.js.
Primary split 5% with The Processing Foundation.

Keys
- 1: view 1000px png (Default)
- 2: download 2000px png
- 4: download 4000px png
- 8: download 8000px png
- s: save the image as PNG

When downloading higher resolution pngs, it might take several seconds to redraw the whole image. Download will start immediately after redrawing is completed. Please bear with the slow rendering.

metadata.name: Sunder: Hills #118
metadata.description:
This is my first experimentation with a new algorithm I call Sunder. The Hill you mint represents you inner-self. It could be colorful, messy, stern, calm, crowded. Reflect on it. I hope you enjoy my work.

Made in p5.js

By twistie

metadata.name: Garden, Monoliths #193
metadata.description:
"Garden, Monoliths" is the result of an algorithm that started in April 2021. It was called "Grass.js".
Spring was blooming all around the house, taking over the stones and remnants of ancient battles that stood here. Inspiration was everywhere.
The initial goal was to use mathematical formulas for creating patterns inspired by the density of nature, that could be used by a pen plotter, so it kept focusing on outputting vector lines. This history and practice produced a graphical style based on line strokes, plus occasionally some transparent, filled shapes.
Each artwork will be either "Garden" or "Monolith", for they are variations of two existing designs from the workshop.

metadata.name: Inertia #444
metadata.description:
This project will be reserved and free for 48 hours, for all the holders of any of my projects!

The amount of reserves for each user will be equal to the amount of all the token held at 13:00 CEST [UTC+2] (May 23)
(example: user holds 3 "Figment" and 2 "ACCUMULATOR", will be able to mint "Inertia" 5 times)

48h from now I will update the reserves list and burn the remaining tokens

WARINING: The reserves will expire 48h after the drop! And a price for the unlocked mintables will be set (unreserved mints will not be free).

---

"Inertia is a property of matter by which it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line, unless that state is changed by an external force."

Particles are blasted from 2 to 4 sides of the canvas, each particle has its own mass and it has to traverse a friction-field, once it loses its momentum completely it stops and leaves a trace, adding or subtracting light from the canvas.

The friction-field has 18 possible mutation kinds.
Mutations are high-friction zones of various shapes.

Made just with JS on a canvas
right-click to save

metadata.name: COMPUTERS #81
metadata.description:
Generative animated painting made from pixel array computations and classic noise algorithms.

COMPUTERS is a meditation on the aesthetics of computing in all of its forms. It recalls the types of computation required to build temples, write complex texts, weave detailed textiles, and program computer games. Pixels have always existed in some form or another, before and after the screen. Every iteration of COMPUTERS suggests that computation is both contemporary and ancient.

Press 'p' or click to pause the animation.
Press 's' to capture a single frame.
Made with P5.js and GLSL. By @galoandstuff.

metadata.name: Ordinary Places #97
metadata.description:
“Ordinary Places” is a fully-coded meditation on the poetic beauty of everyday landscapes. 

The architectural characters in these landscapes include water towers (inspired by Bernd & Hilla Becher’s “Water Tower” photography series), gas stations (inspired by Ed Ruscha’s “26 Gasoline Stations” photography book), and barns (inspired by childhood memories on my grandfather’s farm). 

Yet, while these scenes may seem ordinary upon first glance, something darker lurks beneath the surface. The hidden secrets of these Ordinary Places can only be revealed through the minting process. In this sense, the outputs are not merely a collection individual scenes, but instead, a coherent world animated by shared themes and narratives.     

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.

metadata.name: Blendokush #232
metadata.description:
Inspired by the Android game, "Blendoku", this is an exploration into combining graduated colour arrays in different ways. Each piece begins with a set of 9 base colours. 
Keyboard 'c' will randomly change the way that the colours are combined while keeping all other variations the same.

metadata.name: Dencity #753
metadata.description:
Dencity is a generative art project inspired by aerial views of cities with a high density of buildings. Its perspective effect, its perfectly imprecise lines, its subtle textures and its very advanced level of detail give it the appearance of a hand-drawn work.

Behind the visible art (the image) hides another form of art, an extremely complex algorithm capable of calculating and drawing in 2D each variation of the Dencity project. To draw a variation, the algorithm notably takes around 3,000,000 to 20,000,000 random decisions based on the hash of the mint and draws around 800,000 to 4,000,000 lines to create all the strokes and texture effects.

Made with ❤️, code and p5js.
